awd_titl_txt: Phases and Phase Transitions in Complex Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support research in the structures, called phases, which emerge in systems with many components as the number of   components grows. We will study complex networks, simple models consisting only of abstract nodes and edges between them. These   models are simpler than those traditionally used to analyze phases, and the simplicity will allow us to better understand how phases  transition between one another as control parameters vary, a study of wide application in the sciences and technology. Possible applications range from management of urban construction projects to astrophysics computations and understanding behavior of granular media, such as sand and grain piles.

The prototype of emergent systems are the phases in molecular materials in thermal equilibrium, and they have been studied   intensively, but only special sorts of phases and transitions have  been successfully modeled; in particular there has never been a   satisfactory model of the emergence of the solid phase, or the fluid-solid transition. We will modify the microcanonical ensemble of statistical mechanics to study complex networks, which exhibit phases analogous to solid and fluid phases, and we will exploit the   relative simplicity of these models to better understand such phases and the phase transitions between them.

por.por_cntn:
We studied analogues of the physical phenomena of phase transitions, as exemplified by the freezing of water to ice as temperature and/or pressure is varied. Most of our results concerned the global features of typical large mathematical networks or graphs constrained to have given densities of edges and triangles, the constraints mimicking the constraints of pressure and temperature in materials in thermal equilibrium. We were able to demonstrate, sometimes through proof but mostly through computer simulation, qualitative features that have not been possible to demonstrate in the more complicated setting of molecules because of the experimental dimensions of size and time involved for molecular systems. The accompanying figure, sketching transitions between 14 phases, indicates the higher scale of theoretical results we obtained in the setting of random networks.

We also studied phase transitions in bulk sand, both physically (experimentally)  and theoretically, where energy is carefully put into and taken out of the system through large scale processes, namely put into the system through shear and taken out of the system through friction. We determined specific conditions under which the processes drive the grains to automatically rearrange into a very regular, `crystalline' pattern, strongly reminiscent of the way water molecules rearrange into crystalline ice when energy is removed in freezing. This phenomenon is called nucleation, and is not well understood in the setting of molecules such as water because it is too difficult to follow the relevant motion of individual molecules. For sand we were able to follow the motion of the particles, creating a reliable window into this very general and important rearrangement phenomenon. We then demonstrated the phenomenon of nucleation in phase changes in the setting of large mathematical networks with constraints on edge and triangle densities.
